message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and EEG findings suggest absence seizures. Ethosuximide is the first-line medication for treating absence seizures. Carbamazepine is used for partial and generalized tonic-clonic seizures, as well as trigeminal neuralgia. Phenytoin is used for partial and generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Levetiracetam is used as an adjunct therapy for partial seizures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The 3-Hz spikes and waves on the EEG suggest absence seizures. Ethosuximide is the first-line therapy for absence seizures. Carbamazepine is used for partial seizures, while Phenytoin is used for tonic-clonic seizures. Levetiracetam is used for a variety of seizures but not specifically for absence seizures.

Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for absence seizures. Carbamazepine and phenytoin are effective for partial seizures, and levetiracetam is effective for various types of seizures but not specifically for absence seizures.

Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for treating absence seizures. Carbamazepine and Phenytoin are not effective in treating absence seizures, and Levetiracetam is not the first-line treatment for absence seizures.

The patient’s symptoms and the electroencephalogram results suggest absence seizures, and Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for treating absence seizures. We refer to PubMed articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing absence seizures, which are characterized by 3-Hz spike-and-wave discharges on electroencephalogram (EEG). Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for absence seizures, as it specifically targets T-type calcium channels that are thought to be involved in the pathogenesis of these seizures. Carbamazepine and phenytoin are more appropriate for treating focal seizures, while levetiracetam is used for a broad range of seizure types but is not as effective for absence seizures.
